stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on importing and implementing a large number of 3D assets from artist Biobak into a new level. This involved extensive work in Blender, fixing models and materials, writing custom code for actor behaviors, and troubleshooting collision. Key activities included implementing a complex real-time CPU shading solution for a rotating apple, debugging memory limit crashes, and demonstrating a significant custom rework of the game's core collision engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a new, 'nearly continuous' collision routine to eliminate the randomness of Mario's interaction with slopes, making movement more predictable for the average player.
development_findings.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement. ... I don't want the player to think about their quarter frames when they play my game.

development_findings.summary: Despite improving slope collision, Kaze identified a remaining inconsistency where landing from a jump can cause a variable loss of momentum. He concluded that a perfect fix would require a fundamental engine rework that is too complex to undertake.
development_findings.quote: This is unsolvable without introducing proper delta time physics in Mario 64, I believe.

development_findings.summary: The project is approaching the N64's 64MB ROM limit, currently at 60MB. Kaze plans to remove unused vanilla SM64 assets to free up space.
development_findings.quote: We have 4 more megabytes. ... We really are approaching the 64 megabytes. Crazy.

development_findings.summary: The team ran out of RAM after importing new assets. Kaze resolved this by moving smaller assets to an 'emergency memory pool' to reduce fragmentation in the main pool, highlighting the tight memory constraints of N64 development.
Kaze notes that while armature bones are typically cheap on N64, the specific implementation in the original Super Mario 64 engine is inefficient.
development_findings.quote: On Mario 64's implementation, they are kind of expensive because they did it in a stupid way.

development_findings.summary: Kaze fixed a rendering issue with transparent decals, noting that the original Mario 64 engine renders them in the wrong order, which would have made the effect look like 'dog shit'.
The stream focused heavily on importing and integrating new assets for a disco/factory-themed level, including models, collision, and programming actor behaviors.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in mastering the technical aspects of a tool before creative fun can begin, highlighting a disciplined and skill-first work ethic.
context_findings.quote: My approach to blender was very much not have fun, but rather like... learn the hotkeys and then you get to have fun. Like learn your tools at first and then you get to have fun. That is my approach.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels a pressure to perform development live on stream, which he believes slows down the overall project completion as he relegates bug-fixing to his off-stream time.
context_findings.quote: It's too bad I feel pressured to only work on this on stream so you can know exactly what I'm doing. Because otherwise I probably would have finished this by now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a personal design philosophy that the project should adhere to the original 64MB ROM size limit of the N64, viewing it as a core creative and technical constraint.
context_findings.quote: If you go beyond 64 megabytes you're going beyond what the original Nintendo 64 developers worked with and like that just feels like cheating.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a deep, humorous affection for his robotic lawnmower, which was away for repairs, and mentions his child is doing well and learning to make sounds.
context_findings.quote: You guys know the Gary Come Home song from Spongebob, that's how I feel about my lawnmower.

context_findings.summary: Kaze repeatedly makes sarcastic jokes about his wife, Zeina, 'abusing' him by giving him a haircut, showcasing their playful and banter-filled dynamic.

biobak.summary: Biobak created most of the assets imported during the stream, including the egg, gates, Poochie, a flower shy guy, a rotating stone ball, and a rotating apple.

Biobak's artistic choice to use detailed vertex colors on a rotating apple model created a technical challenge, leading to a compromise where Kaze implemented a custom real-time CPU lighting solution.
biobak.quote: Because Biobak wants his vertex colors on the apple, and I want my shadows on the apple. So we compromise by computing the fucking shadows on the CPU in real time.

biobak.summary: Biobak's newer models are noted to be more optimized in terms of triangle count and materials, which helps with performance and memory.
Kaze mentioned that Biobak has a 'spoopy computer', which may influence their collaborative workflow, such as how assets are organized in different blend files.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife, actively participates in the stream chat, engaging in playful banter and responding to Kaze's jokes about their relationship.
zeina.quote: if that's the case I'll leave the kid and leave and take the kid with me the Yoshi's included

zeina.summary: She provided a new thumbnail for a potential presentation at the F3 fan game expo.
Kaze speculated that an older version of the Flower Guy model was originally created by Zeina before being reworked by Biobak.

key_stories.title: Removing Randomness from Mario's Movement
key_stories.summary: Driven by a philosophy that player movement should be predictable, Kaze rewrote Mario 64's core collision logic. His new system removes the 'random' feeling of sliding on slopes, creating a more consistent player experience, though he acknowledges it's not a perfect solution for all sub-frame issues.
key_stories.challenge: In vanilla Mario 64, Mario's interaction with slopes is inconsistent; sometimes he sticks, sometimes he flies off, depending on sub-frame positioning. Kaze found this randomness unacceptable for players.
key_stories.process: Kaze wrote an entirely new collision routine from scratch. He described it as making collision 'nearly continuous', effectively eliminating the quarter-frame randomness that caused the original problem.
key_stories.outcome: Mario now consistently sticks to and walks down slopes, making movement predictable. This success, however, highlighted a related, more complex problem with momentum loss on landing, which Kaze has decided to leave as is due to its complexity.
key_stories.key_quote: I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind. Like, I don't want the player to think about their quarter frames when they play my game.

key_stories.title: Real-Time CPU Shading for One Apple
key_stories.summary: An artistic choice by Biobak to use vertex colors on a model clashed with the engine's lighting system. To solve this, Kaze undertook a significant technical challenge on-stream, creating a custom, real-time CPU-based shading solution for that single object to preserve the art while adding dynamic lighting.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak designed a rotating apple model with detailed vertex colors. Standard N64 lighting wouldn't work, making the rotating object look flat and lifeless, creating a conflict between the artistic design and technical limitations.
key_stories.process: As a compromise, Kaze decided to calculate the lighting on the CPU at runtime. This involved transforming the level's light vector into the apple's local space by multiplying it by the inverse of the apple's rotation matrix, then applying that light value to each vertex to create a 'shade color' on the fly.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a custom lighting system for the apple. It now has both Biobak's detailed vertex colors and dynamic, smooth shading that rotates correctly with the object, satisfying both artistic and technical goals.
key_stories.key_quote: Because Biobak wants his vertex colors on the apple, and I want my shadows on the apple. So we compromise by computing the fucking shadows on the CPU in real time.

key_stories.title: Fighting the N64's Memory Limits
key_stories.summary: The project hit the N64's RAM limit, causing crashes. Kaze diagnosed the issue as memory fragmentation and used a clever, hardware-specific workaround by reallocating small assets to a secondary 'emergency' memory pool, freeing up just enough space to make the game stable again.
key_stories.challenge: After importing new, complex temple gate assets from Biobak, the game began crashing because it ran out of available RAM.
key_stories.process: Kaze investigated the memory allocation and realized the main memory pool was too fragmented. He identified that the N64 architecture provides a small secondary 'emergency' pool. He strategically moved some small, non-critical data into this pool.
key_stories.outcome: By moving a few small assets into the 'emergency memory pool', Kaze freed up enough space in the main pool to prevent fragmentation and resolve the crash. The game now loads correctly with the new assets.
key_stories.key_quote: We were all over just a couple of kilobytes. So by just chucking some random other stuff into the emergency pool that doesn't need to be in the left pool, we basically freed up enough memory.
